1.brief: elevation, i.e. the act (literally, a journey to a higher place, figuratively, a thought arising), or (concretely) the condition (literally, a step or grademark, figuratively, a superiority of station); specifically a climactic progression (in certain Psalms)
to lift, in a great variety of applications, literal and figurative, absolute and relative
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
near, with or among; often in general, to
a mountain or range of hills (sometimes used figuratively)
where? (only in connection with prepositional prefix, whence)
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)

2.brief: adverb or preposition, with (i.e. in conjunction with), in varied applications; specifically, equally with; often with prepositional prefix (and then usually unrepresented in English)
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
the sky (as aloft; the dual perhaps alluding to the visible arch in which the clouds move, as well as to the higher ether where the celestial bodies revolve)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)

3.brief: not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
to give, used with greatest latitude of application (put, make, etc.)
a wavering, i.e. fall; by implication, a pole (as shaking); hence, a yoke (as essentially a bent pole)
a foot (as used in walking); by implication, a step; by euphemistically the pudenda
not (the qualified negation, used as a deprecative); once (Job 24:25) as a noun, nothing
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.

4.brief: not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to be slack or languid, i.e. (by implication) sleep (figuratively, to die); also to grow old, stale or inveterate
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity

5.brief: Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
the right hand or side (leg, eye) of a person or other object (as the stronger and more dexterous); locally, the south

6.brief: the sun; by implication, the east; figuratively, a ray, i.e. (architectural) a notched battlement
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to strike (lightly or severely, literally or figuratively)
properly, a twist (away of the light), i.e. night; figuratively, adversity

7.brief: Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
properly, a breathing creature, i.e. animal of (abstractly) vitality; used very widely in a literal, accommodated or figurative sense (bodily or mental)

8.brief: Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
properly, to hedge about (as with thorns), i.e. guard; generally, to protect, attend to, etc.
to go (causatively, bring) out, in a great variety of applications, literally and figuratively, direct and proxim.
to go or come (in a wide variety of applications)
at this time, whether adverb, conjunction or expletive
as far (or long, or much) as, whether of space (even unto) or time (during, while, until) or degree (equally with)
properly, concealed, i.e. the vanishing point; generally, time out of mind (past or future), i.e. (practically) eternity; frequentatively, adverbial (especially with prepositional prefix) always
